items.title: Progressively-enhanced Single Page Apps - the future?
items.content:
Together withÂ 

#â€‹563 â€” October 12, 2022 | Read on the web

Now Decided: The Syntax for CSS Nesting â€” If you were one of the 7,590 developers who responded to a recent survey helping to direct the CSSWG in picking a syntax to go with for standard CSS nesting support, give yourself a hearty pat on the back â€“ a decision has now been made. â€œSuch a large split was not estimated but is relieving to theÂ discussions.â€

Adam Argyle

The Webâ€™s Next Transition â€” The web is made up of technologies and architectures that got started over 25 years ago and, to a large extent, have organically grown over time. Now, Kent takes a detailed look at the transition to new and improved architectures (progressively enhanced SPAs) for building webÂ applications, and how changes to multi-page apps are coming about.

Kent C. Dodds

11 Angular Training and Learning Resources â€” Angular has one of the best communities out there. So if you want to get started, itâ€™s easy to find quality training resources. Here are 11 of theÂ best!

Progress Kendo UI for Angular sponsor

Performance Budgets: The Easiest Way to a Faster Site â€” Until you set specific goals, itâ€™s not clear what metrics you want to improve, or how youâ€™ll do it. This post looks at just how to set performance budgets in order to meet and maintain speedÂ goals.

Karolina Szczur

Sustainable Web Development Strategies Within an Organization â€” Climate change and sustainability are increasing concerns for those working in tech â€”Â this article explores some of the ways to raise awareness and effect change within an organization, to create a more positive environmentalÂ impact.

Michelle Barker

âš¡ï¸ IN BRIEF

  • ğŸ“… Smashing Magazine is hosting a free online event next month covering Design Systems, looking at how they work, what they can do for your teams, and how to manage them.

  • Mozilla has taken steps to significantly improve the responsiveness of Firefox on macOS from version 103 onwards.

  • â†‘ You can now see CSS Authoring Hints in Chrome's Dev Tools style pane.

  • Here are the release notes for Safari Technology Preview 155 with updates to Web Inspector, Rendering, Scroll to Text Fragment, the Web API & more.

ğŸ“™ Tutorials, Articles & Opinion

â–¶Â Â The Border Property You Never Knew You Needed â€” The border-image property isnâ€™t anything new, but Kevin shows us how it can be used with more modern styling techniques for fun gradientÂ effects.

Kevin Powell

Delightful UI Animations with the Shared Element Transitions API â€” We shared part one of this two-parter last week. This time Adrian shows us how to create same-document page transitions for Single Page Apps and their future potential for creating cross-document transitions in Multi-Page apps.

Adrian Bece

Layout Breakouts with CSS Grid â€” Extending elements beyond the content area with CSS Grid and named gridÂ lines.

Ryan Mulligan

Register for Unblock 2022 - A CI/CD Conference by Buildkite â€” A free 2-day virtual conference featuring industry experts from companies like Retool & Twilio who are defining the future of how we continuously deliverÂ software.

Buildkite sponsor

â–¶Â Â Animating Triangles with Three.js â€” A 90-minute live coding session covering the creation of a striking animation of a whirlwind of dissolving triangles. You have to see it to get it, but I learn a lot from seeing how other people approach projects likeÂ this.

Yuri Artiukh

New Patterns for Amazing (Web) Apps â€” This blog post announces a new collection of patterns for apps, including clipboard patterns, file patterns, and advanced appÂ patterns.

Thomas Steiner

Practical Uses of the :has() Relational Pseudo Class â€” Demos of what you can do with the :has() pseudo class (which lets you select elements with children matching a supplied sub-selector) from grid layouts to validatingÂ forms.

Brecht De Ruyte

Introducing Shoelace, a Framework-Independent Component-Based UX Library
Adam Rackis

How to Safely Share Your Email Address on a Website
Lorenzo Bonannella

How to Build SVG Line Charts with React, SSR and Tailwind CSS
Paul Scanlon

ğŸ”§ Code, Tools & Resources

Dracula UI: A 'Dark Mode-First' Collection of UI Patterns and Components â€” The components are built for dark mode, available in HTML and React, and can be used for prototyping via a configurable design system and using VS CodeÂ snippets.

Netto Farah & Zeno Rocha

Shoelace: 'A Forward-Thinking Library of Web Components' â€” A collection of well designed every day UI components (buttons, drawers, inputs, menus, color pickers, and more) built in a framework agnosticÂ way. We linked to a handy introduction to Shoelace earlier in this issue :-)

Cory LaViska

Donâ€™t Let Your Issue Tracker Be a Four-Letter Word. Use Shortcut

Shortcut (formerly Clubhouse.io) sponsor

Check HTML Links: A Fast Checker for Broken Links andÂ References â€” An npm package you can run on static pages to find broken links in href, src, and srcset, and can process 500-1000 (local) documents in just a fewÂ seconds. If you already have npm installed, you could try it with npx check-html-links . from a folder of HTML files.

Modern Web

Tailwind CSS Hyphens: Plugin That Adds Support for the hyphens Property

Vivian Guillen

Typography Combination Inspirations â€” Hereâ€™s a large collection of the font combinations used across some of the biggest sites on theÂ web.

Jesco WÃ¼ster

ğŸ§‘â€ğŸ’» JOBS

Senior Frontend Engineer (EU Remote or Relocate to Berlin) â€” Weâ€™ve built a product thousands of people love (see Trustpilot if you donâ€™t believe us). We need your help with React &Â TypeScript.
Feather

Software Engineer (Security) â€” Join our "kick ass" team. Our software team operates from 17 countries and we're looking for more exceptional engineers to join our Security team.
Sticker Mule

Attend Our October 20th 2022 State of Tech Salaries Panel Discussion â€” Join Ladies Get Paid, TopResume and Glassdoor for a collaborative panel discussion covering salary trends, negotiation and employer POV of salary compÂ packages.
Hired

Ipx.

items.title: UI animation whimsy with the Shared Element Transitions API
items.content:
Together withÂ 

#â€‹562 â€” October 5, 2022 | Read on the web

Delightful UI Animations with the Shared Element Transitions API â€” Adrian shares how the Shared Element Transitions API is a â€œgame-changing feature that will enable us to create impressive and elaborate UI animations easily.â€ This post explores the potential by building real-life examples fromÂ scratch.

Adrian Bece (Smashing Magazine)

Templating in HTML with <template> â€” A quick reminder about the <template> element and how it can come inÂ handy, though folks on Hacker News were quick to pick up on itsÂ limitations.

Kitty Giraudel

Build Internal Tools 10x Faster with Retool â€” Assemble your UI, connect data, and publish apps faster than building from scratch. Retool offers 100+ pre-built UI components and the ability to write code to customize how apps look and work. Schedule a 1:1 demo to learnÂ more.

Retool sponsor

The 'New Wave' of JavaScript Web Frameworks â€” A few months ago he covered the new wave of React state management and now Rem is back trying to â€œmake sense of the proliferation of new JavaScript web frameworks.â€ As are we all. Vue, Svelte, Solid, Remix, Astro and Qwik all make an appearanceÂ here.

Rem

More Details on the Transition to Manifest V3 â€” Outlines new details about the (arguably controversial) plan for Chrome to move extensions over to Manifest V3 (basically Chrome's new extension platform) including key dates in January and JuneÂ 2023.

David Li (Chrome Developers)

â¤· 'Chrome's Manifest v3 Push Signals Changing of the Guard' â€” Claims this updated version is â€œhostile to extension developers andÂ usersâ€. We said it wasÂ controversial..
Matt Frisbie

âš¡ï¸ IN BRIEF

  • The State of CSS survey is back for 2022 and is currently seeking responses â€”Â you can fill it out here.

  • Chromium has shared the intent to prototype CSS Nesting, the ability to nest CSS style rules inside other style rules.

  • Philip JÃ¤genstedt shares a quick update/summary of the Interop 2022 effort in this video.

  • Research from Akamai suggests some 13 million domains registered each month are malicious.

  • Elliot Jay Stocks site is now using a variable font - he outlines how it was implemented and some things you may want to think about.

  • One for all font fans: Braun has switched from using Neue Helvetica to a new 'Braun Linear' typeface.

ğŸ“™ Tutorials, Articles & Opinion

Element Timing: One True Metric to Rule Them All? â€” Largest Contentful Paint (aka LCP) is a Core Web Vital thatâ€™s gotten a lot of attention in recent years, but itâ€™s not without its pitfalls. The author shares how Element Timing can be a better way to track the performance of the page elements that matter most to site owners and visitors, especially onÂ SPAs.

Andy Davies (Speedcurve)

Meta on Launching a New Chromium-Based WebView for Android â€” Facebookâ€™s in-app browser on Android devices is being updated in an effort to improve security, performance, and the overall userÂ experience.

Nate Schloss (Meta)

Free Webinar! Sprinkle the Clean Code Magic in Your JavaScriptÂ Projects

Sonar sponsor

When Going Somewhere Does a Thing: On Links and Buttons â€” If it goes somewhere, itâ€™s a link. If it does something, itâ€™s aÂ button. Are those two things always mutually exclusive?

Kilian Valkhof

Will Serving 'Real' HTML Content Make a Site Faster? â€” A good comparison of SSR performance on most of the top full stack JavaScript frameworks. Astro and Sveltekit, two of the newer generation of frameworks, come out on top in many of theirÂ measurements.

Scott Jehl

'I Am Not That Excited About New CSS Features' â€” Some quick thoughts on the flurry of new CSS features we have seen of late and whether adoption of these additional riches may beÂ slow.

Silvestar BistroviÄ‡

â–¶Â Â A Love Letter to DOMPoint and DOMMatrix â€” A quick look at two JavaScript APIs useful for visualÂ effects.

Google Chrome Developers

'Where Web Components Went Wrong (And How We Can Turn It Around)'
Matthew Phillips

The Battle for the Soul of the Web
Kaitlyn Tiffany

ğŸ”§ Code, Tools & Resources

50+ Shapes: Copy the CSS for Just About Any Shape â€” Not just run-of-the-mill stuff (triangle, oval, diamond, etc.) but also unique shapes like a checkmark, yin/yang symbol, octagon, cylinder, and lotsÂ more.

CSS Scan

Tailwind CSS Variant Generator â€” Automatically sort Tailwind CSS classes into shared and unique attributes with this browser-based tool. Hereâ€™s a video showing how you may approach usingÂ it.

Charlie Joseph

Simplify Front-End Performance Monitoring by Analyzing UX Data â€” Analyze user errors in real-time and resolve frontend issues fast. Start monitoring your frontend data in minutes with a Datadog freeÂ trial.

Datadog sponsor

icons.download: A Free Set of Open-Source SVG Icons in 16Â Styles â€” A nice set of icons with strokes in 4 different thicknesses along with options for outline and solid styles, and round vs. sharpÂ corners.

Design Resource

Illustration Link: 80+ Links Where You Can Find Free Illustrations for Your Project â€” A searchable directory that includes stuff weâ€™ve linked to before (and more) but compiled into a singleÂ resource.

Illustration Link

dark-mode-toggle: A Dark Mode Toggle Component for React â€” Not to be confused with the Google Chrome teamâ€™s component of the same name, this one is specifically for use inÂ React.

Anatoliy Gatt

  • Developer browser Polypane just hit version 11, adding new accessibility tools, an updated rendering engine, and a new JSON viewer.

  • Bootstrap version 5.2.2 is out now, with various bug fixes and changes to button hover styles.

  • Stark has a new macOS version of their accessibility design tool.

  • Leafjs is another entrant to the world of Web Component-based frameworks for building modern webapps.

ğŸ§‘â€ğŸ’» JOBS

Full-Stack Engineer (NYC / Remote) â€” 100M+ devices, 100B+ API calls. Radar is looking for Product Engineers to build geospatial devÂ tools.
Radar

Software Engineer â€” Join our "kick ass" team. Our software team operates from 17 countries and we're always looking for more exceptionalÂ engineers.
Stickermule

Find Frontend Engineering Jobs with Hired â€” Create a profile on Hired to connect with hiring managers at growing startups and Fortune 500 companies. It's free forÂ job-seekers.
Hired

ğŸš— .. And Finally

Nightdrive â€” An expalanation of a JavaScript demo/simulation of driving at night time on the freeway/motorway â€” created reasonbly simply by drawing circles on a HTML canvas. There's a full screen version, with music, here.

James Stanley

Ipx.

items.title: The state of the web in 2022
items.content:
#â€‹561 â€” September 28, 2022 | Read on the web

The 2022 Web Almanac â€” This annual â€˜state of the webâ€™ report from the HTTP Archive returns for a fourth edition. It is, as always, a superb, detailed resource (crunching some 44TB of data!) looking at topic areas from CSS and JS, to WebAssembly, SEO, and security. This year also features new chapters focusing on interoperability andÂ sustainability. Other highlights:

  • ğŸ¦ Stefan Judis has an excellent Twitter thread bringing us some of the highlights â€”Â like, 71% of us still using pixel (px) for our font-size declarations.
  • ...and talking of fonts, Roel Nieskens brings together some ğŸ¦ web font facts in this Twitter thread.
  • The WebAssembly page is interesting as it shows just how niche it still is, but also what the most popular use cases are (Amazon IVS at #1, but a Web text hyphenation polyfill at #2..)

HTTP Archive

Build Internal Apps in Minutes â€” Retool is a fast way to build internal tools. Ship apps fast with 100+ production-ready UI components. Teams at Amazon and NBC collaborate around custom-built Retool apps to operate better. Teams of up to five can build unlimited Retool apps forÂ free.

Retool sponsor

GIFs Without the .gif: The Most Performant Image and Video Options Right Now â€” So you want an auto-playing looping video without sound? Well, Ollie claims â€œthereâ€™s really no good reason to use the bulky .gif file format anymoreâ€ â€” and looks at what to doÂ instead.

Ollie Williams

Testing Web Design Color Contrast â€” An overview of three tools and techniques for testing and verifying accessible color contrast of yourÂ design.

Adam Argyle and Charlie Gleason

Use Cases for CSS Comparison Functions â€” Explores a few different use-cases for comparison functions (min(), max(), and clamp()), and explains each one inÂ detail.

Ahmad Shadeed

âš¡ï¸ IN BRIEF

  • Chris Coyier gave a talk at CascadiaJS dubbed 'The Web is Good Now' â€” he shares that it may be "time to take a look at how youâ€™re approaching some of the building blocks of your website because evolutions in browser technology and tooling have made many things easier and better."

  • Cloudflare Images now supports storing and delivering SVG files.

  • Large, Small, and Dynamic viewport units (lv, sv, dv) are coming to ChromeÂ 108.

ğŸ“™ Tutorials, Articles & Opinion

The Power of CSS Blend Modes â€” A few experiments revealing how easy it can be to create something cool looking in just a few lines of CSS via blendÂ modes.

Scott Vandehey

Five Data-Loading Patterns to Boost Web Performance â€” Use a framework? Well, this article aims to help you use it in the most performant way possible (think SSR, caching, event sourcing, etc).

Agustinus Theodorus

Introducing Learn HTML â€” A new, free course from Estelle Weyl to help get you up to speed with modern web development. Covers the document structure, metadata, semantic HTML, headings and sections, with more content on theÂ way.

Rachel Andrew / Google / Estelle Weyl beginner

Email, Slack, and Push Notifications Made Easy â€” Contacting your users should be simple. With Courier you can send multi-channel notifications with clearÂ logging.

Courier.com sponsor

Closing a 30 Pixel Gap Between Native and Web â€” PWAs can now customize the app window and title bar area using the new â€˜Window Controls Overlay APIâ€™, hopefully resulting in a more familiar experience on desktopÂ devices.

Patrick Brosset (Microsoft)

On Better Browsers: Arbitrary Media Queries & Browser UIs â€” A conceptual blog post, imaging a future where the browser has support for arbitrary mediaÂ features.

Kilian Valkhof

â–¶Â Â How to Build a Scrollable Text Gallery in Three.js â€” An attempt at reproducing the striking scrolling text effect on display at Design Embraced. This is typography and â€˜web designâ€™ turned up toÂ 11..

Yuri Artiukh

Experimenting with a New Syntax to Write SVG
yuanchuan

ğŸ”§ Code, Tools & Resources

Radix Colors: A Gorgeous, Accessible Color System â€” Includes 30 color scales that can easily be incorporated in various CSS-in-JS systems or with plain CSS, and guaranteed to pass WCAG contrastÂ guidelines.

workos

Devices.css - Modern Devices Crafted in Pure CSS â€” Thereâ€™s a decent collection of devices, all crafted in pure CSS, including the iPhone 14 Pro, Google Pixel, MacBook Pro, Surface Book, and Apple WatchÂ Ultra.

Yan Zhu

Donâ€™t Let Your Issue Tracker Be a Four-Letter Word. Use Shortcut.

Shortcut (formerly Clubhouse.io) sponsor

Papanasi: A Frontend UI Library to Use with Just About AnyÂ Framework â€” Includes a modest set of components built using component compiler Mitosis and available for Angular, React, Solid, Svelte, Vue, or as WebÂ Components.

Quique Fdez Guerra

Fallback Font Generator â€” A tool to reduce Cumulative Layout Shift (CLS) by adjusting web fonts and system font fallbacks using @font-face.

Brian Louis Ramirez

PostCSS Media Minmax: Writing Simple and Graceful MediaÂ Queries â€” This PostCSS plugin allows you to use the new <= or >= syntax to replace min- and max- prefixes in media queries, which you can read about in the specÂ here.

PostCSS

Tailwind CSS Cheat Sheet: Find Tailwind Class Names for Layout Features
Highscore Studio

ğŸ§‘â€ğŸ’» JOBS

Full-Stack Engineer (NYC / Remote) â€” 100M+ devices, 100B+ API calls. Radar is looking for Product Engineers to build geospatial devÂ tools.
Radar

Find Frontend Engineering Jobs with Hired â€” Create a profile on Hired to connect with hiring managers at growing startups and Fortune 500 companies. It's free forÂ job-seekers.
Hired

ğŸ¦– ...and finally

The opening sequence for the latest season premiere of The Simpsons (yes, it's still going â€” this is the 34th season) features a nod to the offline 'dino' game in Google Chrome. â–¶ï¸ Here's a video.

Ipx.
items.contentSnippet:
#â€‹561 â€” September 28, 2022 | Read on the web

          
        



  





  
  
The 2022 Web Almanac â€” This annual â€˜state of the webâ€™ report from the HTTP Archive returns for a fourth edition. It is, as always, a superb, detailed resource (crunching some 44TB of data!) looking at topic areas from CSS and JS, to WebAssembly, SEO, and security. This year also features new chapters focusing on interoperability andÂ sustainability. Other highlights:


  
ğŸ¦ Stefan Judis has an excellent Twitter thread bringing us some of the highlights â€”Â like, 71% of us still using pixel (px) for our font-size declarations.
...and talking of fonts, Roel Nieskens brings together some ğŸ¦ web font facts in this Twitter thread.
The WebAssembly page is interesting as it shows just how niche it still is, but also what the most popular use cases are (Amazon IVS at #1, but a Web text hyphenation polyfill at #2..)
HTTP Archive 


  
  
Build Internal Apps in Minutes â€” Retool is a fast way to build internal tools. Ship apps fast with 100+ production-ready UI components. Teams at Amazon and NBC collaborate around custom-built Retool apps to operate better. Teams of up to five can build unlimited Retool apps forÂ free.
Retool sponsor


  
  
GIFs Without the .gif: The Most Performant Image and Video Options Right Now â€” So you want an auto-playing looping video without sound? Well, Ollie claims â€œthereâ€™s really no good reason to use the bulky .gif file format anymoreâ€ â€” and looks at what to doÂ instead.
Ollie Williams 


  
  
Testing Web Design Color Contrast â€” An overview of three tools and techniques for testing and verifying accessible color contrast of yourÂ design.
Adam Argyle and Charlie Gleason 


  
  
Use Cases for CSS Comparison Functions â€” Explores a few different use-cases for comparison functions (min(), max(), and clamp()), and explains each one inÂ detail.
Ahmad Shadeed 





âš¡ï¸ IN BRIEF
                           
  





Chris Coyier gave a talk at CascadiaJS dubbed 'The Web is Good Now' â€” he shares that it may be "time to take a look at how youâ€™re approaching some of the building blocks of your website because evolutions in browser technology and tooling have made many things easier and better."
Cloudflare Images now supports storing and delivering SVG files.
Large, Small, and Dynamic viewport units (lv, sv, dv) are coming to ChromeÂ 108.






ğŸ“™ Tutorials, Articles & Opinion




  





  
  
The Power of CSS Blend Modes â€” A few experiments revealing how easy it can be to create something cool looking in just a few lines of CSS via blendÂ modes.
Scott Vandehey 


  
  
Five Data-Loading Patterns to Boost Web Performance â€” Use a framework? Well, this article aims to help you use it in the most performant way possible (think SSR, caching, event sourcing, etc).
Agustinus Theodorus 


  
  
Introducing Learn HTML â€” A new, free course from Estelle Weyl to help get you up to speed with modern web development. Covers the document structure, metadata, semantic HTML, headings and sections, with  more content on theÂ way.
Rachel Andrew / Google / Estelle Weyl beginner


  
  
Email, Slack, and Push Notifications Made Easy â€” Contacting your users should be simple. With Courier you can send multi-channel notifications with clearÂ logging.
Courier.com sponsor


  
  
Closing a 30 Pixel Gap Between Native and Web â€” PWAs can now customize the app window and title bar area using the new â€˜Window Controls Overlay APIâ€™, hopefully resulting in a more familiar experience on desktopÂ devices.
Patrick Brosset (Microsoft) 


  
  
On Better Browsers: Arbitrary Media Queries & Browser UIs â€” A conceptual blog post, imaging a future where the browser has support for arbitrary mediaÂ features.
Kilian Valkhof 


  
  
â–¶Â Â How to Build a Scrollable Text Gallery in Three.js â€” An attempt at reproducing the striking scrolling text effect on display at Design Embraced. This is typography and â€˜web designâ€™ turned up toÂ 11..
Yuri Artiukh 


  
Experimenting with a New Syntax to Write SVG
  
yuanchuan 
  


ğŸ”§  Code, Tools & Resources




  





  
  
Radix Colors: A Gorgeous, Accessible Color System â€” Includes 30 color scales that can easily be incorporated in various CSS-in-JS systems or with plain CSS, and guaranteed to pass WCAG contrastÂ guidelines.
workos 


  
  
Devices.css - Modern Devices Crafted in Pure CSS â€” Thereâ€™s a decent collection of devices, all crafted in pure CSS, including the iPhone 14 Pro, Google Pixel, MacBook Pro, Surface Book, and Apple WatchÂ Ultra.
Yan Zhu 


  
  
Donâ€™t Let Your Issue Tracker Be a Four-Letter Word. Use Shortcut.
Shortcut (formerly Clubhouse.io) sponsor


  
  
Papanasi: A Frontend UI Library to Use with Just About AnyÂ Framework â€” Includes a modest set of components built using component compiler Mitosis and available for Angular, React, Solid, Svelte, Vue, or as WebÂ Components.
Quique Fdez Guerra 


  





  
  
Fallback Font Generator â€” A tool to reduce Cumulative Layout Shift (CLS) by adjusting web fonts and system font fallbacks using @font-face.
Brian Louis Ramirez 


  
  
PostCSS Media Minmax: Writing Simple and Graceful MediaÂ Queries â€” This PostCSS plugin allows you to use the new <= or >= syntax to replace min- and max- prefixes in media queries, which you can read about in the specÂ here.
PostCSS 


  
Tailwind CSS Cheat Sheet: Find Tailwind Class Names for Layout Features
  
Highscore Studio 
  








ğŸ§‘â€ğŸ’» JOBS





  
Full-Stack Engineer (NYC / Remote) â€” 100M+ devices, 100B+ API calls. Radar is looking for Product Engineers to build geospatial devÂ tools.
  
Radar 
  


  
Find Frontend Engineering Jobs with Hired â€” Create a profile on Hired to connect with hiring managers at growing startups and Fortune 500 companies. It's free forÂ job-seekers.

items.title: Web fonts get colorful with COLRv1
items.content:
#â€‹560 â€” September 21, 2022 | Read on the web

First Batch of Color Fonts Arrives on Google Fonts â€” You can customize color palettes, add gradients, and more with the rather fancy COLRv1 font binary vector format. Google Fonts now has nine new typefaces that you can use, or just play around with to get an idea of what this expressive technologyÂ canÂ enable.

Sarah Daily

Discover New HTML Elements & CSS Selectors â€” Join Jen Kramer for this detailed video course on intermediate HTML and CSS techniques, covering semantic HTML, inheritance, specificity, the cascade, and more. You'll also get a hands-on look at using new selectors such as :has(), :is(), andÂ :where().

Frontend Masters sponsor

Total Blocking Time: A Short and Sweet Guide for Happier Users â€” Any delay longer than 50 milliseconds and visitors can sense that a page is 'unresponsive.' Tracking and reducing such delays is vital to avoiding a poor experience. â€œBlinking takes approximately 100â€“400 milliseconds. Thatâ€™s fast, but itâ€™s two to eight times longer than most people will accept when interacting with a rendering webÂ page.â€

Ben Schwarz

â–¶Â Â 'I Never Thought This Would Be Possible with CSS' â€” A ~15 minute video with plenty of practical examples of how you can make use of the :has() pseudo-class, presented in Kevinâ€™s usual accessibleÂ style.

Kevin Powell

JavaScript APIs You Donâ€™t Know About â€” Ok, itâ€™s a bold headline â€” plenty of you will have at least heard of these, but itâ€™s nonetheless a decent roundup to catch up on where the web platform is. Covers APIs like Page Visibility, Web Sharing, and the Broadcast ChannelÂ API.

Smashing Magazine

âš¡ï¸ IN BRIEF

  • Here's what's new in DevTools in Chrome 106, including a Largest Contentful Paint timing breakdown in Performance Insights.

  • Firefox 105 shipped yesterday, here are the (very few) developer changes you need to know about.

  • Stephanie Eckles excellent primer on CSS Container queries has been updated to reflect the syntax now in Chromium 105 and Safari 16.

  • CORRECTION: Last week we shared details of the latest Safari release, incorrectly stating that this version added support for the :target pseudo-class. In fact Safari has supported this for quite some time â€” it's support for :target in :has() which is new. Thanks to Lea Verou for spotting this!

ğŸ“™ Tutorials, Articles & Opinion

Why the type="number" Input is the Worst Input â€” Think that web form has got your number? If you used input type=â€numberâ€, you may be surprised to find that itÂ doesnâ€™t.

Jared Toporek

Smooth and Simple Page Transitions with the Shared Element Transition API â€” This API allows page transitions within single-page apps, and is available as an origin trialÂ now.

Jake Archibald

'React I Love You, but Youâ€™re Bringing Me Down' â€” An opinionated React thought piece. This time, though, the author gets creative checkpointing the progress (or lack thereof) of React over the years in â€˜mix tapeâ€™ style with plenty of code and memes sprinkled in for goodÂ measure.

FranÃ§ois Zaninotto

Donâ€™t Let Your Issue Tracker Be a Four-Letter Word. Use Shortcut â€” The best issue tracking software is one that software developers are actually happy toÂ use.

Shortcut (formerly Clubhouse.io) sponsor

Experimenting with WebTransport â€” A new(ish) API offering low-latency, bidirectional, client-serverÂ messaging. It's a bit more flexible than WebSockets and runs overÂ HTTP/3. Browser support is very patchy so far,Â alas.

Jeff Posnick

â–¶Â Â Talking Cascade Layers â€” Una Kravets and Adam Argyle (Dev Advocates at Google) are back with another season of The CSS Podcast. This episode talks about how cascade layers can help authors control/orchestrate CSS layering. (18Â minutes)

The CSS Podcast podcast

Which Fonts to Use for Your Charts and Tables â€” Sans-serif or serif typefaces? Lining or oldstyle figures? Narrow or wide? With lots of examples, we can see which fonts work best for dataÂ visualizations.

Lisa Charlotte Muth

ğŸ”§ Code, Tools & Resources

Theatre.js 0.5: Hackable Motion Design for the Web â€” Can be used both programmatically and visually to animate 3D objects created with things like Three.js, React Three Fiber, HTML/SVG, or even to â€˜animateâ€™ variable values. v0.5 introduces 3D scene editing and complex keyframing. Docs and GitHubÂ repo.

Theatre.js Project

mediaquery.style: A Quick Reference for Useful Media Query Syntax Snippets â€” Includes seven common media query snippets, with explanations, for those who occasionally forget the exactÂ syntax (all of us, no?Â ğŸ˜†)

Adrian Payne

Seamlessly Add Chat and Activity Feeds to Your Applications

Stream sponsor

Core Web Vitals Check: Bulk Test Core Web Vitals Scores for Up to 500 Pages â€” This tool gives you three different ways to test: a single URL, a list of URLs for bulk checking, or you can enter a keyword to test the scores of the top 50 sites that appear on Google for thatÂ keyword.

experte

Vanilla: A Simple, Extensible CSS Framework â€” Includes a responsive grid, some useful patterns and utility classes, and its composability allows you to only include what youÂ need. From the team behind Ubuntu.

Canonical

ğŸ§‘â€ğŸ’» JOBS

Software Engineers â€” Sticker Mule is the Internet's most "kick ass" brand. Our software team operates from 17 countries, and we're always looking for more exceptionalÂ engineers.
Sticker mule

Find Frontend Engineering Jobs with Hired â€” Create a profile on Hired to connect with hiring managers at growing startups and Fortune 500 companies. It's free forÂ job-seekers.
Hired

Ipx.

title: Frontend Focus
description: A onceâ€“weekly roundup of the best front-end news, articles and tutorials. HTML, CSS, WebGL, Canvas, browser tech, and more.
